# Intro to Hashing 
## and Password Security

## Overview



## Collisions

The "security" of a hash algorithm refers to how hard it is to find an input value whose hash matches a given hash value.
This is called a collision. It doesn't mean you found the original input or password.

There's a max limit of the number of unique outputs for a given algorithm - this is determined by it's output bit length.

A 32-bit hash function (e.g. CRC-32) can represent around 4.2 billion inputs (2^32 or 4,294,967,296.)
A SHA-256 supports 256 bits of output - exponentially larger, at 2^256 ([see common bit length reference table below](#bit-length-data-limits)).

### Bit-length data limits

|Bits | Unique Values `len(n)` | Unique Values |
|:----|:-----------------------|:--------------|
8 | 3 | 256
16 | 5 | 65536
32 | 10 | 4294967296
64 | 20 | 18446744073709551616
128 | 39 | 340282366920938463463374607431768211456
160 | 49 | 1461501637330902918203684832716283019655932542976
224 | 68 | 26959946667150639794667015087019630673637144422540572481103610249216
256 | 78 | 115792089237316195423570985008687907853269984665640564039457584007913129639936
384 | 116 | 39402006196394479212279040100143613805079739270465446667948293404245721771497210611414266254884915640806627990306816
512 | 155 | 13407807929942597099574024998205846127479365820592393377723561443721764030073546976801874298166903427690031858186486050853753882811946569946433649006084096
1024 | 309 | 
2048 | 617 | 
4096 | 1234 |
